title: Will formal negotiations between Russia and the United States on a new nuclear arms control treaty or an extension/modification of an existing nuclear arms control treaty begin before 1 October 2019?
preds: The US government under current leadership has shown a general disdain for treaties. Treaties of this nature would curtail business opportunities for American defense contractors, something the current administration would be loathe to do. Additionally, considering recent decisions by the legislative branch, the administration will likely be occupied elsewhere.

With only one week looming, there is still no indication of an extension or modification of nuclear arms agreements. Discussions have dried up and both Russia and the United States seem keen on waiting until 2020.
No signals for any negotiations. These will most certainly not happen in the next 10 days

On August 2, 2019, President Donald Trump announced the United States' would be exiting the INF treaty due to Russian noncompliance. President Donald Trump has also stated that the treaty should by renegotiated to include China since they have risen to become a major economic, political, and military power. This is not the first time that the United States has accused Russia of being in violation of the treaty and Russian officials are under the impression that they are remaining compliant with the accord.  Since the United States wants to include China in a "future" treaty I find it highly unlikely that all parties will be in agreement and there will not be discussions held prior to 1 October 2019. However, there is a small possibility that there can be formal discussions to address the issue.

On 2 August 2019, President Trump pulled the US out of the INF treaty leaving the New START treaty being the only "treaty limiting US and Russian nuclear arsenals." Reason for this was due to indications Russia was violating this treaty. Based on this, and zero dialogue as of today, formal negotiations will not begin before 1 October. https://www.globalzero.org/updates/your-new-start-explainer-the-value-of-cooperation-on-nuclear-arms-control/?gclid=CjwKCAjwk93rBRBLEiwAcMapUQrnGWQkJWhCB8c6M5WyHO5XH77qgnu3fWZbKfCZT0FN43JqVri_UhoCM8UQAvD_BwE

It is unlikely the United States and Russia will engage in a formal negotiation of nuclear arms control before October 1st 2019. While both sides have expressed interest in reopening negotiations, there has not been any tangible evidence to suggest the scales are tipping in that direction. Instead, over the last month, both countries have continued to test previously banned weapons. Consider the Russian's Skyfall, Poseidon, Dagger, Avengard and the United States' "Low Yield" tactical warheads (https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/ne8nkw/all-the-absurd-new-weapons-russia-is-building-in-the-new-nuclear-arms-race) The Arms Control Association, responsible for helping to establish working groups for foreign leaders to discuss nuclear disarmament have had no success over the last several months at helping reach an agreement between the United States, Russia, and other countries. "The next meeting of the CEND initiative has not been announced, but some reports have indicated it will take place later this year in Europe. Finland, the Netherlands, and South Korea will serve as co-chairs of the three discussion subgroups, and three additional co-chairs are expected to be named." (https://www.armscontrol.org/act/2019-09/news/us-hosts-nuclear-disarmament-working-group)  As of September 4th 2019, the United States completed the INF Treaty Withdrawal, signaling the treaty's official death. With only the New START in place, expected to expire in February of 2021, I beleive both countries percieve the horizon for nuclear weapons exploration to extend beyond 1 October 2019 and thus will have little desire to engage in formal conversations until 2020. Putin was right all along. The Pentagon stressed that the missile tested Sunday was “conventionally configured,” meaning it was not outfitted with a nuclear warhead. However, the dissolution of the treaty, along with new weapons tests, has heightened fears of a burgeoning arms race. The Pentagon uploaded slow-motion imagery of the test-flight, which showed a Tomahawk cruise missile emerging from a Mark 41 (Mk-41) Vertical Launch System. The footage was significant because it proved one of Moscow’s biggest fears about U.S. Aegis Ashore missile defense systems operating in Poland and Romania. Russia had complained for years that those systems, which use Mk-41 launchers, could be converted into INF-violating attack systems by swapping out SM-3 interceptors with Tomahawk missiles. The U.S. response was the Mk-41 wasn’t prohibited under INF because it had never been tested with a ground-launched missile. It may have been correct, but the Kremlin’s concerns appear to have been well founded.

https://www.state.gov/new-start-treaty-inspection-activities/ The New START Treaty provides for 18 on-site inspections per year. There are two basic types of inspections. Type One inspections focus on sites with deployed and non-deployed strategic systems; Type Two inspections focus on sites with only non-deployed strategic systems. Permitted inspection activities include confirming the number of reentry vehicles on deployed Intercontinental Ballistic Missiles (ICBMs) and deployed Submarine Launched Ballistic Missiles (SLBMs), confirming numbers related to non-deployed launcher limits, counting nuclear weapons onboard or attached to deployed heavy bombers, confirming weapon system conversions or eliminations, and confirming facility eliminations. Each side is allowed to conduct ten Type One inspections and eight Type Two inspections annually. New START Treaty Inspection Activities Treaty Year nine

A recent meeting between Russian and US officials to discuss fraught related to arms control is a strong indicator that the involved counterparties intend to start a formal discussion about the issues at hand. No further meetings have been agreed on, however, such talks represent a crucial step for possible future negotiations.  In the end, the likelihood for the start of formal negotiations will be adjusted by 6% in favour of ‘yes’. Both counterparties proved that they are able to discuss the issue despite recently deteriorating relations. Furthermore, the summer recess would be beneficial to kickstart informal talks without the burden of internal politics. On the other hand, upcoming military exercises, new sanctions and a climate of mistrust likely delay the next meeting as this area might be misused as a bargaining chip in a wider range of negotiations about several issues concerning the national security of both countries. Update: Last week, at an economic forum in St. Petersburg, Putin commented on the lack of development in the START negotiations. Arguing that Russia has been pushing for the nuclear arms treaty talks to begin, the US, in contrast, have been stalling and made no moves to move negotiations along. Consequently, Putin said that Russia will just not extent the treaty, if the US is not interested in beginning talks. Putin speaking so bluntly on the topic seems to underline Russia's dwindling desire to pursue these negotiations. In combination with recent remarks on Russia's arms production abilities, Putin seems to be emphasizing Russia's position as a leading military power and as such, a country that does not need treaties. 
Just around the same time, leading democrats send a letter to Trump urging him to engage with negotiations and seek an extension on the START treaty, as they feared the potential consequences of a lack of treaty. Trump has not responded  this query, and does not seem interested in prioritizing this issue. 
This current situation seems a long way away from any formal negotiations to commence, and I adjust my forecast accordingly.

Update (9/06/19) In my frst forecast, I adopted a rational approach to the possibilities US and Russia have in the renewal/non renewal of an arms control treaty. In this update I decided to drastically change my approach as well as my forecast, considering mainly two articles I recently happened to read (https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2019/04/25/nuclear-security-arms-control-and-the-us-russia-relationship/ and https://www.rferl.org/a/putin-says-russia-prepared-to-drop-arms-control-treaty-if-u-s-not-interested-in-renewal/29984790.html). First of all, looking at the history of the arms control treaty between the two superpowers, it is noticeable how the first efforts generally begun from the US part, followed by a Russian side showing less interest in drafting a treaty to enhance their bargaining power. Apparently with the Trump administration, which will most likely still stand in October, thearm control barganining changed: the US are showing less interest in re-arranging the situation, even if facing the incoming end of the New START. Putin obviously can't show weakness, instead he has to show diplomatic muscles by saying that Russian security can be assured even without an arm control treaty. At this point it is not very likely that Trump and Putin will show signs of backstepping from their positions - thsi consideration relies purely from the consideration of the leaders' personality and constructed role in international politics. Moreover, "U.S. and Russian officials in the past have held strategic stability talks to take a broad look at developments that affect their strategic relationship. Such talks are useful, particularly when new developments, such as those in the cyber and space domains, emerge and when Russian nuclear doctrine has provoked concern in Washington and led to changes in the U.S. nuclear posture. Even if strategic stability talks do not spin off specific negotiations, they provide a venue for the sides to exchange views and better understand the concerns of the other. During the Trump administration, a one-day session of strategic stability talks took place in September 2017. As of March 2019, it has not agreed to a second meeting". If a new treaty or the extension of the New Start will happen, it will probably happen with the new US administration. 
In a few months I will know if my previous approach would have been more accurate than this new one. I think this one relies more on the diplomatic history in arms control between US and Russia, but the psychological and contextual variables can be unpredictable.

As @anneinak stated, this question could also be read as “will formal negotiations … begin before 1 October 2019?”. For this reason, the aim of this forecast is to a) find an applicable base rate and complement it by analyses of b) the interest of the USA and the Russian Federation and c) factors indicating the current political relations between both states. Both variables (b & c) have a positive/negative influence on the overall motivation for extending or signing an agreement.  A)	Past trend of nuclear treaties: 
This forecast will use the considerations of @Macbook_pro who bases his/her baseline on the assessed trends by @mbayer123 (examined probability of withdrawal from international treaties by Trump administration) and @IcemanPolitics (calculated a baseline through comparing years of nuclear agreements to the ones without). @Macbook_pro concludes that the timespan of 40 years is too long as the political environment changed fundamentally (e.g.: collapse of USSR). Furthermore, he/she emphasizes correctly the risk of a negative bias by only researching withdrawals of agreements. His/her result, before including the influence of an ‘inside view’ analysis, is 9,19% (final result after including inside view is 2,28%).  @Macbook_pro’s inside view analysis seems correct, regarding the importance of potential economic benefits for the US and budgetary constraints in the case of Russia, but the estimated influence of these on the final base rate is, in my opinion, too high. As a consequence, this forecast will use the (≈) 9% base rate as starting point.  B)	Interest in new/extended treaty:  
The current “New START” agreement will expire in 2021 but includes the possibility for a five-year expansion until 2026. Trump first rejected a proposal of Putin to extend the New START treaty in February 2017. Later on, at the Helsinki summit in July 2018 both presidents didn’t manage to reach an agreement again despite displaying good will. Both sides declared their interest to maintain the agreements. However, regarding US accusations that Russia isn’t complying to agreed rules and Russia’s position that it adheres to the rules at any time, make it seem less likely that both countries are able to reach an agreement soon. Furthermore, the Trump administration already requested a budget for the development of land-based intermediate missile systems and emphasized the strategic importance of its nuclear modernization program. Nonetheless, the Trump administration might oppose Obama’s New START agreement and disagrees with its limits, but it could be that Trump is trying to draft a new arms control treaty which stipulates rules in line with US interests. According to US officials, including General John Hyten, New START supports US strategic interests after all. However, General Hyten stressed that the treaty has to be expanded in order to include new Russian nuclear capabilities which impose a threat to the USA.  However, Russian officials (like Anatoly Antonov, RU ambassador in USA) refuse to include new Russian weapons systems under New START or any other treaty. Russia will only decrease its military capabilities through a new agreement under the condition that the US will agree on limits of US military systems (such as ballistic missiles) as well. Regarding the central importance of nuclear deterrence for Russia’s strategy, it seems unlikely that it will be willing to make generous concessions. Nevertheless, Russian officials stated that they would be willing to enter negotiations with Trump, but that they don’t expect a breakthrough in arms control agreements regardless. Furthermore, in February 2019 Putin stated that he won’t initiate negotiations with the US on nuclear arms agreements. A reason for this deliberate passivity could be that the country isn’t interested in the maintenance of nuclear arms control treaties after all. According to Jon Huntsman of the Moscow Times, Russian officials informally checked if the US would agree to mutually end the INF treaty already in 2004 due to a secret development of a missile system which presumably violates the INF treaty. These aren’t strong signs that Russia will accept any new agreement, however, there’s still a possibility that Russian diplomats will enter into talks with the US in order to maintain a collaborative image on the international stage.   Another issue worth to mention is that the limitations stipulated in treaties/agreements like New START and INF don’t address militarily emerging states like China. China’s PLA rocket forces comprise of 95% missile systems which would violate INF limits. This explains the reluctance of Chinese officials to join arms control agreements and treaties as it would result in a loss of area-denial abilities – a crucial skill in the Chinese defence strategy. As a result, the US has a strategic disadvantage in regard to the deployment of such systems. This might decrease the US’ interest to expand or sign new arms control agreements as it could use these systems to deter Chinese advances in contested regions such as the South or East China Sea. Russia also acknowledged China’s stockpiling of such weapon systems and started to reach out to China in order to include the latter one in future agreements. C)	Political relations between USA and Russia: 
The INF treaty had been initiated by Reagan and Gorbachev to prohibit land-based intermediate range missiles. It doesn’t include similar air- or sea-based missile systems. The US started to withdraw from the INF treaty based on their accusation of Russia for noncompliance with stipulated agreements after the latter had introduced a land-based cruise missile. Russia denies that it broke the treaty, as it claims that the latest missile system adheres to rules set out in the INF treaty. Russia on the other side accuses the US for being responsible for the recent deterioration of arms control treaties. It argues that the US withdrawal from the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty (limiting missile defence systems) forced Russia to react by developing weapons which are able to circumvent these defence systems in order to maintain Russia’s nuclear deterrence. More arms control treaties had been undermined in the last years such as the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces or the so-called Open Skies (stipulated limits for military surveillance activities). The implementation of the New START treaty represents an exception than the rule concerning the historical trend in the last two decades.  Furthermore, the US and Russia face each other as adversaries supporting different warring factions in conflicts such as the armed conflict in East Ukraine, the civil war with multiple factions in Syria, the struggle over control of two main camps in Libya or the different stance of both countries towards Iran and its regional politics. Indeed, these conflicts resemble the proxy wars of the cold war era. The result may be that both states will try to use negotiations over disarmament and/or the development of new nuclear capabilities as another bargaining chip against the other side, hence, reducing the chance that existing treaties will be expanded, or new ones agreed on. These opposing interests, as well as accusations of US politicians and the US media that Russia illegally influenced the US elections, resulted in the imposing of new sanctions against Russia by the US. Indeed, the US has increased steadily the number and the scope of these sanction programs against Russia and its strategic partners in the last years. Trump presumably good relationship with Putin is nullified, because the anti-Russia stance became the new common ground for bipartisan cooperation between Democrats and Republicans.  However, the current relation between both countries should be evaluated in the context of the 1980s, the decade before the first START treaty had been signed. Tensions between the USSR and the West soared due to USSR’s Afghanistan invasion in 1979. The election of Reagan (1980) increased tensions further as the US president implemented his Reagan Doctrine which aimed to undermine the influence of the USSR by supporting resistance movements against communist governments across the globe. Military exercises of the US and its allies, like Able Archer in 1983, represented a new peak of mutual mistrust and a crisis comparable to the Cuban missile crisis. Relations between both countries started to improve when Gorbachev became the new general secretary of the USSR in 1985. Nonetheless, the START treaty was initiated in 1982 by Reagan at a time of extraordinary tensions. As a result, the current political relation between both countries could be evaluated as more stable than during the early 1980s, despite recent negative developments as mentioned before (or current remakes of military exercises by NATO or Russian troops). However, this doesn’t mean that formal negotiations are more likely as higher tensions influence political actors to react by addressing and reducing these. The latest developments could also be interpreted as the first phase in a new cold war (as some foreign policy commentators do). This means that the pressure on both presidents to de-escalate might not be as high as it was back then.    The initial base rate of 9% will be decreased to a 4% probability that new formal negotiations will take place before the 1st of October. This probability will be decreased each month by 1% given the absence of significant events which support an increase of the assessed probability. As a result, there will be a 1% chance in September. The reason for this conclusion is that most actions and events tend to have a negative influence on the interest or motivation to enter formal negotiations. Economic circumstances (as described by @Macbook_pro), current and future developments of new (nuclear) weapon systems, the challenge through China’s emerging military capabilities and ambitions, the recent trend of weakened or unilateral cancelled arms control treaties, the conflict of strategic interests and finally the limited amount of time left until the 1st of October. The two significant arguments for an increase of the probability aren’t convincing enough after a second review. Both countries’ presidents and their officials declared their interest in maintaining these arms control agreements but in the same time both states are unwilling to make concessions in order to reach a compromise. Another supportive argument is the comparison of the cold war to current times and the conclusion that tensions aren’t as high as they once were. Considering the negative developments, this comparison turns out to be more counterproductive than supportive for arguing in favour of formal negotiations. Either both presidents aren’t under as high pressure to find a compromise as the former presidents back then or the current events represent the first phase in a new cold war. Taking into account the current context of the U.S and Russia relationship, as well as, changes in the security environment, it is highly unlikely that negotiations will begin before 1 October 2019.  In my analysis, I mainly rely on an internal view. To my mind, there is a little relevance to analyse those type of treaties from the external view, for instance, looking at other similar treaties and how often they are extended, due to a shortage of data. There are not a lot of cases from other countries that could be weighty enough to compare it to the U.S. and Russia. As a result, we can only compare this case to the previous 5 treaties among the U.S and Russia, that started in 1969. Looking on past treaties and circumstances among them it is barely possible to find one pattern that we could rely on as the period is full of withdrawals, unfinished negotiations and etc.  From the internal view, circumstances changed a lot compared to the ones in 2010. As of today, as for Russia, Russia has started a war in Ukraine in 2014, meddled in the U.S Presidential Elections 2016, used a chemical weapon Novitchok in the UK and poisoned their own agent and his daughter in 2018. What is important, pieces of evidence are sound enough not to raise any doubts about Russia's involvement. Regarding the U.S, Trump's extraordinary personality is barely comparable to any of his predecessors. In this case, it is quite hard to see any coherent position towards Russia and its actions. Some days it looks like Putin is seen as an enemy, while another - as a friend. 
Besides that, there is some sound evidence why it is very unlikely for the negotiations to begin before October.
First, both countries exchanged accusations of Nuclear Arms Control Treaty violations towards each other. As a result, the U.S suspended the treaty. 
Second, there are obvious changes in the security environment. According to State Department Undersecretary Andrea Thompson, “When the treaty was negotiated, the U.S was in a more benign security environment, where relations between the great powers were less tense and mistrustful". She is specifically pointing to Russia’s invasion and annexation of eastern Ukraine. Even though it could be argued that Russia's invasion of Georgia did not stop the U.S from signing the treaty with Russia in 2010, Ukraine's war cannot be seen from the same perspective. One of the reasons - United (almost) EU position towards Russia.
Third, the important factor here is also a short time period (4,5 months). Even if could predict that despite many tensions the agreement might be reached in the future, there are no positive signs or nice gestures showing that it can be reached within 4-5 months from now.  Sources:

The forecast at hand is an assessment of 3% chance of formal negotiation between Russia and the United states on a new nuclear arms control treaty or an extension/modification of an existing nuclear arms control treaty to begin before October 1, 2019. Below are the main reasons why I believe that the new strategic arms reduction treaty between Russia and the US won’t be amended in the nearest future. Additionally, I assume that there’s very low likelihood that there’s going to be a discussion about new treaty between the countries. 	First of all, I would definitely exclude the possibility of negotiations about a new treaty. If we look into the theory of arms controls and the history of previous agreements, we’ll see that it’s a difficult process, that is time consuming and there are certain events that lead to it. So far, the tense relations between Russia and the US haven’t given us any reason to think that there might be another arms control treaty negotiation developing in the upcoming months. After Russia invaded Georgia in 2008, it might have been smart move from the US to reduce the number of strategic nuclear missile launchers by half in order to control Russian aggression. However, the invasion of Ukraine in 2014 proved that no treaty/negotiation is actually capable of decreasing the possibility of Russian military interventions in other states. Furthermore, the Russian interference in the US presidential elections and poisoning of Sergei and Yulia Skripal further affected the relations between the countries.  	Second, New START (Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty) entered into force on February 5, 2011. It replaced the Treaty of Moscow (SORT), which was supposed to expire in December 2012. If the parties decide to extend or modify already existing treaty, it means it will most likely take place in 2020. However, after Trump pulled the US out of the Cold War-era Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty in February 2019, causing Russia’s frustration, it is very unlikely that the parties will negotiate further extension or amendment of the New START. Trump has also demonstrated throughout his presidency that he doesn’t trust the deals that were negotiated by Obama. Furthermore, Trump has said that “For too long, we have been held back by self-imposed limits while foreign competitors grow and they advance more than we have over the years”. Pentagon has also announced that it is going to spend about a half trillion US dollars over a decade on new nuclear weapons, even though the poll from the Center of International and Security studies reveals that the US citizens actually prefer “a more constrained nuclear posture” and are very skeptical of weapons that already exist. Currently Trump has been discussing a possibility of highly ambitious treaty that will include Russia and China and all the weapons, warheads and missiles. Hence, negotiations regarding the extension/modification of the treaty isn’t on the agenda of the US government.  	Finally, if the parties will still decide to start negotiations regarding nuclear arms control, I believe that current frustration between them needs to reduce first and it will definitely need more than 5 months. Earlier this year Trump pulled the US out of the INF and has historically been critical of Obama's New START deal with Russia. Trump has a tendency to pull out of Obama negotiated deals but is never eager to renegotiate them, i.e. the Iran Nuclear deal and Paris Climate accords. Furthermore, these negotiations require a fair bit of political maneuvering and intent signaling before formal negotiations begin. As of now there has been none of this. Pulling out of the INF could've been a way to increase pressure to bring Russia to the table and increase the US's bargaining position. However, neither side yet to show a willingness to  renegotiate.  Also I find it more than likely that Trump would prefer to let Obama's START deal lapse, rather than extend it, based on his previous handling of Obama deals and his criticism of START. If both side are keen to negotiate a new Nuclear deal then I predict it'll take more time for them to cool off over pulling out of the INF and then there will have to be months of maneuvering and signaling  before talks can be made on when and where negotiation could happen. I find this to be a process that'll take longer than 6 months and therefore find it unlikely, but not impossible that formal nuclear negotiations could begin before October 1st 2019.

I think that is very likely that Russia and the US will implement a new treaty or will introduce some modifications to the text because both of them they have recently increased their military capacity and updated their technologies.
To be more clear, I compare the current New START to the previous one, the START treaty negotiated in the ‘80s. At that time the tensions between the two superpowers was higher than today, and so was the fear of the capabilities and intentions of the other: that treaty reflected the suspicion and the uncertainty of those years, including strict limits on nuclear proliferation. Instead, the New START has been stipulated in 2009 and “does not contain layers of limits and sublimits; each side can determine its own mix of land-based intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs), submarine-launched ballistic missiles (SLBMs), and heavy bombers.”. It doesn’t forbid the states to modernize strategic nuclear forces, even if the goal of predictability and transparency of their intention is still present. This fact has allowed Russia and US to develop their offensive nuclear technologies, so will be necessary to modernize the treaty too. I would also add that Russia is currently in a bad economic situation, and I can’t imagine as a brilliant idea from Putin put himself in the position of raising the military expenditure in absence of an agreement with the US: this would mean more taxes and more dissatisfaction among the population.
Another reason, is the necessity of an agreement between the two powerful state about army proliferation. Indeed, after reciprocal accusations about not respecting the INF, both the State withdraw from it. So, now it is fundamental keeping at least another agreement alive and concrete, both to avoid the risk of proliferation and to not damage even more the historically troubled relations between Russia and US. 
In addition, a renovation of this treaty would be an occasion to contrast the rise of China: indeed it has established a cooperation with European countries and is investing an impressive flow of money in infrastructure to control the markets in a not so far future (ex. The construction of BRI). In front of such a plan and because of the recent trade war that Trump has engaged with China, the US have better to keep Russia on its side at least in this field.
In addition, I argue that China is also developing its nuclear arms, which could be interpreted in two ways: as the reason why continuing having bilateral agreement between Russia and US is useless, because other big countries instead are becoming more aggressive, or as the reason why is necessary at least maintaining the order and pursuing cooperation, also signing bilateral agreements like this or even include the “enemy” (China) in order to control it. - But not before 1st October 2019

Base Rate for the forecast at hand are the decisions of the Trump administration to leave or formally re-negotiate international treaties and memberships in international organizations. Due to the high degree of uncertainty in terms of the current US administration’s international policies, and the discrepancy to former US government’s policies, the forecast excludes the time prior Trump’s election- even though there were already withdrawals prior, such as the US withdrawal from the Treaty on the Limitation of Missile Defence Systems (ABM Treaty). Following withdrawals were detected: 
On January 23, 2017, Trump signed an executive order to renegotiate NAFTA, with the intention of obtaining a more favorable deal for American workers. Eventually, Canada, Mexico and the US agreed upon on replacing NAFTA with the USMCA treaty on September 30, 2017 after formal renegotiations (http://www.wongfleming.com/trump-updates-2018-trumps-treatment-of-international-treaties-immigrants-and-refugees/). 
On January 23, 2017, Trump withdrew the US from the TPP Agreement, promoting closer economic cooperation between the signing states, without formal re-negotiations (Ibid.).
On January 23, 2017, Trump formally abandoned the TTIP negations for a free transatlantic economic zone and declared an “end to the era of multinational trade agreements.” (Ibid.) 
In August 2017, Trump announced that the US would be withdrawing from the Paris Climate Agreement with the possibility of rejoining “if the terms improved for the United States.” Two formal negotiation sessions have taken place since then but only pro forma since the US cannot withdraw officially before three years after the agreement entered into force (Ibid.).
On October 12, 2017, the US notified the UN's culture and education body, UNESCO of their. decision to withdraw from the organization and to seek to establish a permanent observer mission to UNESCO instead. The United States has walked out of UNESCO once before under ex-president Ronald Reagan, who quit in 1984 over alleged financial mismanagement and claims of anti-US bias in some of its policies (https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2017/10/274748.htm).
On May 8, 2018 the US administration officially withdrew from the JCPOA Deal that in a nutshell aimed to block Iran from building nuclear weapons in exchange for the abolishment off a variety of sanctions. No formal re-negotiations have taken place since then. Instead, the US administration pressures its western partners and companies to abolish Iran-related business (https://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2018/05/281938.htm). 
On June 19, 2018 the US left the UN Human Rights Council, “an organization that is not worthy of its name.” No formal re-negotiations have taken place since then (https://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2018/06/283341.htm) . 
This record of withdrawals from international treaties and organizations since 2017 stresses the attitude of the current US administration towards these regimes. Only in one out of the 7 cases (14%), real negotiations have taken place - considered the fact that those in the context of the Paris Climate Accord were just formal procedure. Particular meaningful for the question to be answered is the US’ withdrawal from the JCPOA and the US’ efforts to undermine other states’ efforts to uphold it without the US.  Turning to the nuclear arms control treaty, the US administrations announced on February 1, 2019 that the US will suspend its obligations under the INF Treaty and initiate proceedings to withdraw from the Treaty. Thus the contract is completely suspended on August 2, 2019 (https://www.zeit.de/politik/ausland/2019-02/usa-steigen-aus-inf-abruestungsvertrag-aus). According to the US, there would still be a chance not to suspend the contract. However, Russia already declared one day later that they would suspend compliance with the treaty themselves (Ibid.). This is the worst starting position for the soon necessary extension of the New Start Treaty. Should it fail, from 2021 the strategic nuclear weapons of the USA and Russia would not be subject to any legally binding restrictions for the first time since 1968. 
Both Russia and the US have several geo-strategic reasons to abolish the INF treaty. Next to the Trump administration’s above demonstrated negative attitude towards international collaboration, the US accuses Russia - backed by its NATO allies - to violate the treaty’s conditions. Respectively, Russia accuses the US to do the same. On top of that, China, not a contracting party of the INF treaty, and its INF arsenal, would also contribute to the strategic disadvantages  resulting from the treaty for the US, according to Trump. Consequently in order to enforce a solution, the US would increase its nuclear capacities, as long as there were no trilateral treatment in place. Russia, on the other hand is facing its neighboring states in the south and east in possession of INF systems, as well as the general mistrust against and rivalry with the US, further promoted by Putin (https://www.swp-berlin.org/publikation/der-inf-vertrag-vor-dem-aus/).  The above described context supports and reinforces the base rate assumption of the forecast at hand. While based upon the base rate a likelihood of 14% had to be estimated, the geo-political strategies of both actors and the US administration’s strategy in the context of the JCPOA, further reduces these chances. Hence, the forecast at hand estimates a likelihood of 4% that formal negotiations will take place  before October 1, 2019.

For a number of reasons, it seems very likely that formal negotiations between Russia and the United States on a new nuclear arms control treaty or an extension/modification of an existing nuclear arms control treaty will begin before 1 October 2019.  The clearest and recent one is the accuses of the USA to Russia of having violated the INF (testing of the RS-26 Rubezh solid-fueled intercontinental ballistic missile) and the following unilateral decision to abandon the treaty. And this one has represented only the last step at least one-year period where Washington and Moscow have been touting nuclear weapons plans in what to many has seemed like a throwback to the Cold era. In addition. The very recent declaration of Russia says that it won’t destroy missiles U.S. claimed by the USA as breaking INF made relations between 2 countries only worse.  Then, if Georgia should really join Nato (there are ongoing negotiation), Russia would go on a rampage and act in the less cooperative way possible (and maybe rather in the most aggressive possible). Furthermore, there are all those actions and events which have contributed in rising tension over the recent years (e.i. annexation of Crimea, Syria, disinformation campaign/accusations etc) which led to a huge lack of confidence from both sides. Last but not least, Trump more than one time has referred to the new Start as a “bad deal” implemented by the Obama administration.  Another key reading sees Russia and Usa less and less interested in bilateral agreement now that the nuclear threat might come by so many different actors. Particularly, the Usa are concerned by China and its quickly increasing nuclear program. Therefore, both Russia and the USA might abandon their long-lasting bilateral management of nuclear weapons and start a new path including (at least) China. However, doing so would also mean to recognize the legitimacy of existing nuclear programs and the definitive loss of their bilateral approach.

That said, overall I assess a 75% chance that a new nuclear arms control treaty or an extension/modification of an existing nuclear arms control treaty will NOT begin before 1 October 2019.  Nevertheless and although the crowd consensus is at 5%, I decided to leave a 25% chance for the following reasons:
-Trump and Putin praised their intentions to continue nuclear arms control during the last Helsinki summit. Also Russia’s ambassador to the US Anatoly Antonov have recently stated that the deterioration of arms control would be against both interests of the two states.  Yes, they definitely could be just “bon ton declarations”, but they could also hide common concerns and the unwillingness of a new arms race. 
-The “New START” has a much greater symbolic value of the INF. Letting it dying would mean put the word end to one of the cornerstones of the arms control process. In other words, it would mean throwing in the rubbish 50 years of difficult and long negotiations. Are the USA and Russia really willing to start a new arms race and with it a new Cold war (even though according to some scholars is already ongoing)? Russia is in a terrible economic condition and raising taxes to pay arms production and research would make it only worse. On the other hand, rising the military expenditure could cost to Trump votes, at least on the long run (although Trump claims that raising the military production would be beneficial for the economy). 
-The recent communication of the filing of the Trump-Russia investigation which Trump celebrated as a victory might also let him feel less judged in being more collaborative with Putin. 
-They have all the interest to make a new agreement which includes China as well and the expiry of the treaty could be a good “excuse”.  That said,  I do not assess more than a 25% chance of negotiations starting before 1 October 2019 anyway. This because, even though for the reasons mentioned the two countries could perhaps opt for a new agreement or for the revision of the actual, I consider October 2019 still too early. As typical in Russian-American relationship, also in the case of a positive outcome they would before play the so-called chicken game (two players drive cars at each other, the first to swerve away and slow down loses and is humiliated as the chicken) and, hence, start negotiations at the closely to the very end of the expiring treaty or even after this occurs. Trump's withdrawal (and subsequently Putin’s) from the 1987 Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces (INF)Treaty amid claims that Russia has been violating the agreement, are likely to implicate the prospect of nuclear arms negotiations in the near future: ‘Richard Burt, who served as chief negotiator in the original START talks between the U.S. and Russia, said the INF decision is “very bad news for anybody who is a supporter of extending New START”’ (Mehta, Defence News 23 Oct 2018). James Acton, from the Carnegie Nuclear Policy Program, has said: ‘Russia, I think, would agree to extending New START even if the US withdraws from INF. The problem is that it’s increasingly clear that this administration doesn’t want to extend New START’ (Mehta, Defence News 23 Oct 2018). Since the decision does not formally have to be taken until 2021, whether the treaty will be extended or modified will be largely dependent on the result of the US 2020 elections. Ultimately then, it is considered highly unlikely that negotiations will commence before October 1, 2019.

Following the withdrawal of the INF by both the US and the Russian Federation, the perspectives for negotiations seem to be compromised in the short run. Putin has declared that Russia will not take the initiative for further negotiations on disarmament in response to the US move of withdrawing first. Moreover, since the allegations against Russia are supported by the NATO State members e.g France, I believe that this strengthens the reasons for Putin not to engage the discussion (first) of any time soon.  
Hence, if Pompeo declared that Washington was open for further negotiations with Moscow, I believe that the ball is in Trump’s administration’s court. 
I find highly unlikely that we will witness a new arm race in the following months. Instead, I find very likely that Trump will engage in new negotiations, but when? Trump made a point of honour that during his presidency, he will be the man who succeeded in bringing Washington and Moscow closer together, and in particular on the crucial question of nuclear power. Thus, despite the dissent and strategic benefits (from a realistic point of view in IR) of the current situation — e.g deterrence towards China — I find most likely that Trump will seek to re-discuss with Moscow. However, we could expect Trump’s administration to leave the 6 months of withdrawal for Moscow to change rifle of shoulder and convince Washington of its goodwill. In that sense, I believe that what will happen in the following months will determine the future perspectives on the New START treaty. Nevertheless, considering Trump’s doctrine (opposing Obama's works), it is very probable that Trump is seeking to create a new treaty with Moscow and  — from a strategic point of view — we could expect such move to occur closer to 2020 if Trump wants to present for presidency again.

First, there is the willingness of President Trump and President Putin to continue the nuclear arms control treaties, as explained at the Helsinki summit of 2018. However, they need to resolve some of the "existing problems related to the Treaty Implementation" 
(such as Russian's noncompliance with the INF treaty and other arms control agreements). These problems will be conducive to delaying negotiations for an agreement, pending the resolution of these different, and given the New START 2021 deadline, perhaps October 2019 may seem a bit early. Indeed, the confidence gap between the two countries seems to push the percentages of success of the beginning of a negotiation of a new agreement or an extension before 1 October 2019 down.
The negotiation of an extension seems to be the only solution for the beginning of a negotiation before October 2019. The extension is supported by certain analysts of the American government, because it would allow certain advantages (limiting the number of deployed strategic nuclear weapons in Russia, avoiding misperceptions) and by providing additional five years to possibly reach new agreements on further reductions or transparency measures (source: https://fas.org/sgp/crs/nuke/R41219.pdf). However, Trump and his administration seems unwilling to extend the treaty, preferring to redo another. Indeed, the U.S. President has said that it is one of many bad deals the Obama administration negotiated for the United States. In the idea of a new agreement,  some people explaining that the US and Russia could either renegotiate the treaty or replace it with something more like the 2002 Moscow Treaty. One possible option is to negotiate a new treaty that retains the most salient features of New START, such as limits on deployed forces and robust transparency and verification measures, but addresses matters of particular importance to the United States, such as the number of nonstrategic nuclear weapons possessed by Russia, or new types of nuclear delivery systems. However, in that case, it may not provide a capable or timely response to the expiration of New START. Indeed, Russia has been unwilling to accept limits on its nonstrategic nuclear delivery vehicles in the past, and any attempt to convince them to do so in the future may require the United States to agree to the elimination of its nuclear weapons deployed in Europe. Neither side is likely to accept the demands of the other, an effort to renegotiate New START would likely fail to produce a new treaty before its 2021 expiration (source : https://fas.org/sgp/crs/nuke/R41219.pdf). In sum, there is more likelihood for a negotiation of a new treaty, but it is very likely that given the current state of US-Russian relations and the 2020 presidential US campaign, the beginning of negotiations will happen in 2020 or even in 2021.

Excluding the outcome in which Russia and US stopping the cooperation in nuclear arms control (hope not), four different outcomes are possible.
A) In the event that US and Russia decide to renovate the New START, they could
1: open the formal negotiations to renovate it right in the aftermath of its end (after 1 October 2019). 
2: open the formal negotiations to decide to renovate it earlier (before october 2019)
In this situation, the real question is: if the intent is to maintain the New START deal, why should Russia and USA open formal negotiations almost 2 years in advance? 1 is much more likely than 2.
B) In the event that US and Russia decide to sign a new deal for nuclear arms control, they could
3: open formal negotiations before the 1 October 2019
4: open formal negotiations in the proximity of the New Start deadline (after 1 October 2019).
In this situation, many more variables come into play (main actors' preferences, contractual power of the two countries, willingness to find a deal, time required to actually write a deal that can meet both the parties' necessities and preferences and so on). Such a delicate issue requires a lot of thinking by both parties and the time required to actually write this kind of deal is a lot, so I would suggest that 3 is much more likely than 4.
Here it is requested to assign a probability to the event 2 and 3 considered together: while 2 is not much likely, 3 is actually probable. Now the question becomes which one between A) and B) is more probable. Given the recent developments, I would say that a new deal (B) is slightly more probable than the maintainment of the New START - even if drawing a new deal in such delicate issue is not a lighl decision to do. Considering all together, this is a draft of the probabilities I would assign to each outcome:
No Deal: 1%

1: 39%

3: 35%

dropping back. reasons being: 1)  'Formal negotiations is such a loose term, even Oracle-internet doesn't seem to have clear definition. But "new nuclear arms control treaty' in Q is pretty clear. That rules out a meeting where the agreement details aren't the sole focus; such as someone referring to modifying or eliminating, say, clause #.#; or section 1A,  (As opposed to a discussion about arms, treaties, or violations) 2) Russia doesn't think it has violated the agreement. So any discussions along lines of "Russia, either you agree to stop violating, or else we [USA] will withdraw," is not negotiation. It's a diplomacy tactic to get one side to 1) comply with agreement,  or 2)  get one side to admit to a violation.  2A) Both of these would be precursors to 1) US formally withdrawing (or Russia)  or 2) US/Russia formally agreeing to some sort of change in international behaviour which would, one would seriously hope to expect, be ADDED to contract through formal negotiations. Really, would compliance be sorted with a handshake and a verbal agreement? I have to say "No thanks." Arms reductions play-by rules really should be written down. 3) Russia  could still fancy themselves better off without restriction of treaty which is how the US views the agreement; as constraining them while allowing other countries (non-Russian ones like China and Iran) to potentially keep amassing weapons. Then Putin and Trump would formally agree (probably very nicely) to nix it together. Buds forever. 4) I don't think, even if we assume Russia has been in violation several times, since treaty inception (and it probably has - Second worse coverup in history?), Russia is not the bad guy in this treaty thing. Other countries are in Trump's crosshairs ( bad pun). Trump wants Russia's help to thwart Iran collecting Uranium and making parts; control Syrian hot potato/musical chair thing where $$$, trafficked goods, UN resources, etc all pass through that country and  trickle north, south, east and west to aid neighbouring country fights. Saudi Arabia seems to have its own wacky plans, Yemen, etc.  5) As Bolton says, START will be included  in Nov talks, but so might other topics (China? Syria?Trade? Oil?) or might be more of a quick televised meet-and-greet -- especially, since this would be the first time the two have met since the nasty election biz. The focus then wouldn't be on treaty so not, to my mind, formal negotiations. 6) If meeting is  short (10 minutes - 45 minutes? )  then more likley goes to 'discussion' bin, and not 'formal negotiation" bin. 6) Trump tends to slam stuff out there as a tactic, to see where the chaff falls. Worked for him here, as Russia was taken off guard and adopted a friendly, rather than pugnacious tone which puts them mentally in the headspace of giving something (slight) up, as opposed to stubbornly holding fast.  7) The news articles say "Putin emphasized the need to maintain a dialogue, saying he would be ready to meet with Trump in Paris during centenary commemorations next month marking the end of World War I." "Dialogue" goes to discussion bin, not negotiation, I think. Anyway, I just don't think question should resolve as yes based on Nov 11th meeting even if Putin and Trump talk about START, and even if they talk about withdrawing. That's just bro conversations. However should the mods feel differently I am prepared to rev this baby up to 100% in under six seconds. My two cents, all.

Adviser to the President of the United States on National Security John Bolton - on the talks in Moscow
https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/3778456
John Bolton, US national security adviser, is visiting Moscow . On Monday, he held talks with Security Council Secretary Nikolai Patrushev, after which he told Kommersant correspondent Yelena Chernenko about the reasons for the US withdrawal from the Treaty on the Elimination of Medium and Short Range Missiles (1987) and the upcoming meeting of Presidents Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump. - How did your negotiations with Nikolai Patrushev go? Is it true that you came to Moscow primarily to bury the Treaty on the Elimination of Intermediate-Range and Shorter-Range Missiles (INF)? - (Laughs.) Today was my second meeting with Nikolai Patrushev and the staff of the Russian Security Council. The first time I met them was before the summit in Helsinki. I came to prepare the ground for a meeting between Presidents Trump and Putin. Patrushev at the time seemed to be in South Africa. So I met with his deputy (Yuri Averyanov - “Kommersant” ) and other colleagues. Patrushev and I first met in Geneva in August. In any case, this is the second meeting after Helsinki, it was scheduled about six weeks ago. Now is just the right time to meet. We arrived with a broad agenda. Many issues - for example, arms control and all related topics - were discussed in Geneva in August. We discussed them then and planned to do it again in Moscow. And we had these plans before the President’s Saturday statement (on the US intention to withdraw from the INF Treaty. “Kommersant” ). What you need to know about the agreement on the elimination of medium-range and shorter-range missiles
History, the essence and importance of the contract - in the material "b" - So you are not a messenger from Trump, who came to discuss the details of the process of the US withdrawal from the treaty? - In my opinion, the President (Donald Trump - “Kommersant” ) on Saturday made a very strong, clear and direct statement about his views (on the future of the INF Treaty - “Kommersant ”) and what will be the US foreign policy in this area. What to do with the contract and when to make it public - he decides as the president of the USA. What I did today (and I will do tomorrow) was the way the president’s thoughts were explained and what the next steps might be. - Can you explain to us? What are the reasons for this decision? - Five or even more years ago, during the presidency of Barack Obama, the United States concluded that Russia committed substantial violations of the INF Treaty, was involved in the production and deployment of missiles that do not comply with the terms of the agreement. The Obama administration has called on Russia to return to fulfilling its obligations. The Trump administration called for the same. But based on Russian statements, it became clear that they (the authorities of the Russian Federation— “Kommersant” ) do not at all believe that some kind of violation took place. And today, during the talks, my Russian interlocutors very clearly expressed their position - that this is not Russia that violates the INF Treaty, but the United States. Now, some say: "This is just a negotiating move by President Trump, and if we could force Russia to return to the fulfillment of obligations, the treaty would be saved." But this is impossible from the point of view of logic. It is impossible to return to the implementation of the arrangements of someone who does not believe that something is breaking.
This is the reality we face. As the president said, Russia is doing what we think is considered a violation of the agreement, and we will not tolerate it without being able to respond. We do not think that withdrawal from the agreement is what creates the problem. We think that what Russia is doing in violation of the INF Treaty is the problem.
Second moment. No one except us in the world is bound by this treaty. Although this is technically incorrect: lawyers will tell you that the former USSR countries (with the exception of the three Baltic republics, which the US never recognized as part of the USSR), were also bound by the treaty when the USSR collapsed. But the remaining 11 countries do not have any ballistic missiles. That is, only two countries in the world are bound by the INF Treaty. One of these countries violates the agreement. Thus, there is only one country in the world bound by the terms of the document - the USA. And this is unacceptable. At the same time, we see that China, Iran, the DPRK - they all strengthen their potential with methods that would violate the INF Treaty, if these countries were its signatories. Fifteen years ago, it was possible that the agreement could be expanded and made multilateral. But today it is already impracticable in practice. And the threat from China is real - you can ask countries such as Japan, South Korea, Taiwan or Australia what they think about the Chinese (missile. - “Kommersant” ) potential. They are nervous about this. Many in Europe and the Middle East are nervous about Iran’s potential. As the President explained on Saturday, this puts the United States in an unacceptable position. And that is why he promulgated the decision (on withdrawal from the INF Treaty. - “Kommersant” ). - In the author’s column in The Wall Street Journal in 2011, you stated that the INF Treaty “has long outlived its usefulness and needs to be revised, or it must be abandoned.” However, at that time no one blamed Russia for any violations. In this regard, there are assumptions that you are just looking for a pretext to withdraw from the contract. “We have not met with you before, but I can tell you that more than once in the past six months, journalists have told me:“ You wrote like this in a certain year, but this and that was said on television ... ”Watch ... What is said and written is already said and written. And I generally do not disown this. But now my job is not to make decisions in the field of national security, but to give advice on national security. And this principle is adhered to by all advisors. And the president, believe me, makes decisions himself. - Can Russia do something to make the United States change their mind about withdrawing from the treaty? - The President has already spoken on this topic. If Russia had eliminated all of its weapons, created in violation of this treaty, and if China did the same, the situation would be different. But I think that the probability of this is zero. - And there is no chance to make the treaty multilateral? In 2007, Russia and the United States at the UN spoke in favor of this, but this initiative was never implemented. - Yes, and this topic was discussed even back in 2001–2004, when I was working in the George Bush administration as deputy secretary of state for arms control and international security. Perhaps, if we, at a sufficiently early stage, took some action, it would be possible. But now, for example, between a third and a half of the total number of Chinese ballistic missiles do not conform to the INF Treaty. And supposing that they (the Chinese authorities— “Kommersant” ) would destroy, perhaps more than half of their ballistic missiles, is simply unrealistic. - Do the United States plan to produce and deploy missiles in Europe that can quickly reach Moscow after withdrawing from the treaty? And will you do the same in Asia? - We have not made decisions on this. But I can say that this is another treaty anomaly. Technological anomaly. Now sea-based cruise missiles have a range that falls under the INF Treaty. But since they are located on American ships in the Baltic Sea, they do not violate the treaty. And if you move them to the coast of Poland, it will already be a violation. What was expected from the talks between Moscow and Washington on the INF But all this empty talk, not related to the more important problems. And the US sees a problem here in a global sense. We are concerned about the violation of the treaty by Russia, its possible actions in the European theater (military operations. “Kommersant” ). But we are also concerned about the East Asian theater, the South Asian theater, the situation in Iran and the Middle East. These are global challenges that led to the conclusions and decisions that we made. - The European allies of the United States, including France and Germany, reacted negatively to the statement by Donald Trump about his intention to withdraw from the INF Treaty. Does the US not care about their opinion? - We consulted with them. The British Secretary of Defense said that he was strongly on the side of the United States in this matter. - But he was the only one. “But this is a very important country, considering its defense expenses.” I am convinced that Japan and other countries will support us. We will continue to consult with our NATO allies on this issue. We have already begun this process and will continue it. - The Russian reaction was also extremely negative. Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov said that the US is “blackmailing” Russia ... - This is generally not true. Let's go back to the beginning of our conversation. This is a Russian breach of the INF Treaty brought us to the current point. And it lasted five years, if not more. - Your interlocutor, Nikolai Patrushev, must have made counterclaims to you in violation of the INF Treaty. Have you been able to address the concerns of the Russian side? - You know, in our Pentagon there are more lawyers per person than in the military department of any other country. And if something is not right, then it will definitely not escape from them and they will not fail to declare it. So I am absolutely sure that we do not violate the INF Treaty.
- Let me ask you about the future of the Treaty on the Reduction and Limitation of Strategic Offensive Arms of 2010 (START-3.— “Kommersant”). Russia proposes to extend its action, the US has already decided on this? - No, we haven't decided yet. But we were discussing START-3 today. This agreement expires in 2021. So we still have time. I have been involved in arms control for many years and I know that many decisions are made at the last moment. Now in the US there is a discussion of what to do with this agreement. One of the points that we consider important is to first resolve the issue with the INF Treaty. I talked about this with Nikolai Patrushev and others (representatives of the leadership of the Russian Federation— “Kommersant” ), explained our logic, we try to be open in this regard. - Did you discuss the possible meeting between the two leaders and when it might happen? - Yes, we discussed this. And I told Nikolai Patrushev what opportunities we see in this regard. He said that he would hand over everything to President Putin. I do not want to anticipate the decision of the Russian president, but perhaps in the near future we will have something to tell you. - The press discussed Paris and Buenos Aires as possible places to meet. - Well ... You have identified two places where they (Presidents Putin and Tramp.– “Kommersant” ) will both be (at multilateral meetings in November . - “Kommersant” ). But we can also imagine a full-fledged summit, like the one that was in Helsinki, in some other place.

What the Security Council told about the five-hour meeting of Patrushev and Bolton‍
https://www.gazeta.ru/politics/2018/10/22_a_12030313.shtml
The first day of the visit of Advisor to the American President John Bolton to Moscow was devoted to the dialogue (Rus for negotiations) on the START and INF Treaty. These topics were touched upon during the Bolton talks with the head of the Russian Security Council Nikolai Patrushev and Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov. The possibility of extending the START Treaty says that the United States is still ready to conduct a strategic dialogue with Russia, despite the desire to leave the INF Treaty, the expert said. The head of the Russian Security Council, Nikolai Patrushev, and US National Security Advisor to the President, John Bolton, held on Monday, October 22, a meeting that lasted five hours. As noted in a press release quoted by RIA Novosti , the parties exchanged views on the extension of the treaty on the reduction and limitation of strategic offensive arms (START) after 2021 for another five years. Bolton himself said that he and Patrushev had very serious discussions on arms limitation, the parties discussed various options for a new START treaty. In addition, he said that Now the United States better understand the Russian position, and they want to clarify the details. The START III Treaty between Russia and the United States entered into force in 2011. The agreement provides for the reduction of deployed strategic carriers on each side to 700 units and to 1,550 nuclear warheads. Messages about the possibility of extending the contract for 5 years until 2026, that is, when the term of stay of the current presidents of Russia and the United States, Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump , ends, gives some hope that this agreement can be maintained. As the leading IMEMO researcher Sergei Oznobishchev notes in an interview with Gazeta.Ru , "The message of readiness to extend the treaty means that the United States is ready to conduct a strategic dialogue with Russia." According to the expert, "we only need to send it in the right direction for us." It can be assumed that if the START III treaty is extended, it will become a kind of “deal” between Donald Trump and Russia in the event of his withdrawal from the treaty on the elimination of medium and short-range missiles (DRSM). This agreement, signed in 1987, is considered the cornerstone of international security. According to this treaty, both the USSR and the USA destroyed a whole class of operational-tactical missiles in Europe. US President Donald Trump said earlier that the United States could withdraw from the INF Treaty, and accused Russia of violations of this agreement. However, this decision may not be final - Trump made it clear that a new version of the treaty is possible, if China also participates in it. It is known that China has a large number of medium-range missiles, and Washington sees them as a threat to their interests in the region and the interests of their allies. The topic of the INF Treaty was discussed not only during the meeting between Bolton and Patrushev , but also during the working dinner of Bolton and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, which took place on October 22 in the Foreign Ministry mansion. The reaction of the Russian Foreign Ministry on this issue is already known. Deputy Foreign Minister of Russia Sergei Ryabkov called the American position "blackmail". Some experts believe that Trump's statements are aimed at forcing Russia to influence China - it is beneficial for Washington to join Beijing in the treaty. Oznobishchev, on the other hand, believes that Trump, as a businessman, wants to conduct a definite deal with China, suggesting that China give up missiles in exchange for ending the trade war. However, according to the expert, such an agreement looks "unrealistic." Trump's statements about a possible exit from the INF range caused an ambiguous reaction both within the United States and in the world. Republican Senator Bob Corker warned that the announcement of withdrawal from the treaty could lead to the cancellation of other agreements on weapons issues. However, Corker suggests that Trump’s last statement can only mean his desire to put pressure on Moscow. In turn, British Defense Secretary Gavin Williamson said that the UK "with full determination" supports Washington in this matter, and called on Moscow to "restore order," reports Financial Times . But German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said that Trump's intention "raises difficult issues for us and Europe." It is worth noting that during the period of the "cold war" in the territory of Great Britain were American medium-range and short-range missiles, which provided a direct threat to the USSR. It is possible that after the UK’s exit from the EU, missiles of this class may reappear there. Experts also believe that US missiles may also appear on the territory of Poland and Romania, where elements of the US missile defense are located. “The risk of a nuclear war in Europe is increasing by an order of magnitude,” said Igor Korotchenko, editor-in-chief of the publication National Defense . He expressed this opinion on the program “The Right to Vote”, which aired on Monday, October 22. Trump administration officials expressed doubts the 2010 New START arms treaty will be extended over concerns about Moscow's failure to comply with that and several other arms treaties.  The Pentagon, meanwhile, is moving ahead with designing a new ground-based missile to counter Russia's illegal cruise missiles built in violation of the 1987 Intermediate-range Nuclear Force (INF) Treaty.  Andrea Thompson, undersecretary of state for arms control and international security, told a Senate hearing Tuesday that Russia's new strategic weapons announced in February, are a factor in whether the United States will seek to extend New START.  "No decision's been made at this time," she told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. "All options are on the table." Among the options being considered are withdrawing from New START; re-negotiating inspection and verification provisions as part of treaty extension; or adopting a more limited and simple agreement similar to the 2002 Moscow Treaty that called for significant reductions in strategic offensive arms.  "Among issues to consider will be Russia's decision to manufacture compliance issues regarding U.S. weapons, and the uncertainty of whether or not Russia's recently announced strategic nuclear weapons will be held accountable under the treaty," Thompson explained in her prepared testimony. In response to U.S. questioning of Russian treaty violations, Moscow has responded with disinformation and false counter charges of U.S. noncompliance.  "Russia's response to each of these situations is to employ its standard playbook of distraction, misinformation, and counter-accusations," Thompson said.   David Trachtenberg, deputy undersecretary of defense for policy, also said extension of New START is uncertain.  "Any decision on extending the treaty will, and should be, based on a realistic assessment of whether the New START treaty remains in our national security interests in light of overall Russian arms control behavior," Trachtenberg testified.  Trachtenberg said the arms treaty provides for on-site inspections and monitoring that are useful and beneficial. However, he added: "That said, what I find particularly troubling is the overall nature of Russian arms control behavior and what the Russians seem to be doing in terms of selectively complying with various provisions of treaties and selectively non-complying with others when they feel it's not in their interest." Russia has launched a large-scale nuclear modernization that includes new missiles and submarines in addition to new revolutionary arms.  The United States is investing more than $1.2 trillion over the next 30 years to modernize its aging nuclear forces, including new ground-based missiles, new missile submarines, and a new bomber.  Russian President Vladimir Putin in February disclosed several new strategic weapons systems violate new START.  The new arms include nuclear-armed hypersonic cruise missiles, a long-range nuclear-powered missile, and an underwater drone submarine capable of delivering a massive, multi-megaton nuclear warhead. Under New START, Russia is obligated to notify the United States that the new weapons are under development and will be counted under the treaty. Sen. Marco Rubio (R., Fla.) asked Thompson whether the announced new Russian weapons are covered under New START.  "They would count as strategic weapons," she said, noting that the Russians have not made any notification of the new weapons.  Thompson also said the new strategic weapons under development by Russia have not been discussed in U.S.-Russian arms talks and she could not say if the U.S. side had asked the Russians about the New START-accountable weapons.  Rubio said that Putin's speech describing new strategic weapons should have triggered someone in charge of arms control to question the Russians about them and "if that's true, you need to notify that [because] that violates START."  "Senator we're taking action on it. We haven't done it through the formal New START process with our counterparts," Thompson said.  Rubio later commended Thompson for recognizing the need to determine whether Russia’s new arms are covered under New START before any decision is made on extending the treaty.  "These new kinds of strategic arms could be destabilizing, so the United States must directly raise its concerns about these emerging systems with the Russian Federation at every opportunity, if it truly hasn’t done so already," Rubio told the Washington Free Beacon. Republicans and Democrats on the committee appeared divided over whether to extend New START.  Sen. Bob Menendez (D., N.J.) suggested that abandoning New START in 2021 could prompt the Pentagon to seek a "larger and more expensive nuclear force."  Sen. James Risch, (R., Idaho), said he opposed the New START treaty when it was ratified by the Senate in 2010 and noted the difficulty of dealing with the Russians on any arms accords.  "Trying to negotiate with people who are not negotiating in good faith is a problem," Risch said.  Risch opposed New START because "I don't have any confidence that [the Russians] are negotiating in good faith," he said.  "They're serial cheaters. They're serial liars and you have to look at the other things they are doing in the world to judge what kind of a mind these people have as far as whether they're acting in good faith," Risch said.   Thompson said in addition to the INF violations and potential New START violations, Moscow violated a ban on the use of chemical weapons in conducting the assassination attempt against a Russian defector and his daughter in England.  ...Moscow also is tacitly supporting Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's use of chemical weapons attacks in Syria, she noted.  Trachtenberg said New START was concluded with the idea of building better relations with Russia. Since then, ties have deteriorated and "we must be clear eyed about the threats we face," he said. In addition to INF and New START issues, Russia also is not adhering to the Conventional Armed Forces in Europe Treaty, the Budapest Memorandum on security assurances, the Helsinki Accords, and the Presidential Nuclear Initiatives on tactical nuclear arms, he said.  Moscow also is violating the Open Skies Treaty while selectively implementing the Vienna Document on exchanges of military information, Trachtenberg said.   Committee Chairman Sen. Bob Corker (R., Tenn.)said: "Out of four agreements—New START, the INF Treaty, the Open Skies Treaty, and the Chemical Weapons Convention—we have significant problems with Russian compliance of three of them." "This system is designed to be a direct counter to Russia, and the United States has made it clear that we will cease pursuing its development if Russia returns to compliance with the treaty," Thompson said.  Two Russian defense contractors involved in the SSC-8 missile, Novator Design Bureau and Titan Central Design Bureau, were sanctioned in September. Posted May 1, 2018
The Trump administration plans to conduct an interagency review on whether to extend the 2010 New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (New START) with Russia, according to two Trump administration officials. Robert Soofer, deputy assistant secretary of defense for nuclear and missile defense policy, told the Senate Armed Services Committee on April 11 that the review would begin soon and assess the “pros and cons” of extending the treaty. Expiration of the accord in 2021, without a replacement, would remove numerical caps on U.S. and Russian nuclear arsenals for the first time since the 1970s.
Friedt noted that if the treaty expires with nothing to replace it, “then we will have less insight” into Russia’s nuclear forces. But she hinted that the administration will take its time before making its decision. An early extension would not “necessarily help” improve the U.S.-Russian arms control relationship, she said. “We have until 2021, and I think we should look at it
very carefully.” Some Republican members of Congress, such as Sen. Tom Cotton (Ark.), have expressed concern about a potential extension given Russia’s violation of other arms control agreements and development of new nuclear weapons delivery systems not limited by New START. “Given that set of circumstances, I think we should take a serious second look at extending” New START, he said at an April 11 Senate hearing. The House-passed version of the fiscal year 2018 National Defense Authorization Act would have prohibited the use of funds to extend New START unless Russia returns to compliance with the INF Treaty. (See ACT, September 2017.) The final version of the authorization bill signed by Trump in December did not include that provision.

On the one hand, Russia has become very public in the last 5 years about their efforts to expand their military and rely on their own manufacturing (some of which is still behind US or other countries), but they've been especially good about showing off their terrifying nuclear weapons and monstrous capacity.  In general I think this is likely to make US opinion even more mistrustful and reciprocal in nature.  However, President Trump has shown himself to be much more likely to be less concerned and more lenient toward Russian than the average American or US politician.  So I suppose it's possible.  Still, I think a more aggressive attitude on both sides is more likely than careful diplomatic discussions, as neither side benefits politically right now from a public discourse of relaxed tensions or peaceful diplomacy, even if we would all benefit from real checks that encourage safety.   Although I think neither side wants actual conflict, the appearance of readiness and reciprocal strength is appealing, and discussions about possible plans for negotiations help moderate that risk somewhat.  But not only does setting up formal negotiations usually take time, I think neither side is likely to agree to begin negotiations until they feel like they are in a rather stronger position than they are now.  Also, actually setting up and going to negotiations (or worse, agreeing to them) also limits some of the nationalistic pride felt (especially in Russia, but also growing in the US) at being a major economic and political world player that others have reason to treat cautiously.  If someone like Obama were in office, I'd put the likelihood much higher, since he preferred moderated, diplomatic foreign policy.  But Trump generally prefers to negotiate things he's sure he can win or look good at negotiating even if they fall through.  He might look good negotiating with Putin (and Putin could agree if he thought he could look like he was playing Trump) and managing a show of being someone who knows the right people and how to make deals that win points, but I don't see Putin needing such a treaty as much as the US and I think Trump is more likely to talk about than do it.  That's because ultimately I think Trump is more likely to look weaker through such negotiations than stronger.  Trump is far less interested in the pragmatics than the theatrics of politics and policies.   Likely the existing treaty will stand with a lot of talk and little move toward formal negotiations for some time.  So maybe by next Fall negotiations are possible, especially as the 10 year mark of the New START treaty approaches.  But if there is a move toward this, I don't think anything will be seriously discussed concerning "formal negotiations" until either late this year or early Spring next year.  And I think it's more likely that talk will be extended and real negotiations delayed, and as they get more realistic, more cautions and criticisms will come out about them and what it means.  This storm's still a ways off, I would guess.  I'll check back in then and see if I feel differently.
